awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This research will integrate approaches from many disciplines including biology, engineering, and physics to analyze and quantify the function of biological molecules important for long-distance electron transfer (LDET) in microbial communities. This research will span hierarchical scales studying how genes and proteins enable the assembly of filaments of bacterial cells that electronically interact with materials present in the environment. Insight into the genetic rules governing microbial LDET has implications for designing multicellular communities to maintain and regenerate nutrient cycles to address global scale challenges in agriculture and sustainability. Knowledge gained during this effort will also enable the construction of novel microbial electronics where cells with modular genetic programs can be coupled to electrodes using LDET through conductive cellular filaments. Additionally, the Fellow will develop an interactive Paper-based Organism Waste Energy Recovery (POWER) device to enable high school and undergraduate students to electronically interact with microbes. The POWER device will allow students to interrogate how different genetic programs alter electricity production and illustrate electrochemical and electrical engineering principles.
 
Microorganisms contribute to Earth-scale biogeochemical processes by regulating electron transfer across a range of spatial scales. Recently, bacteria living in aquatic sediments were discovered that perform LDET by forming filaments of thousands of cells spanning centimeter-scale redox gradients found in these environments. Thus far, it has not been possible to isolate and grow these ‘cable bacteria’ in pure culture. This challenge has limited the throughput of research on understanding the genetic rules governing this unique LDET phenotype. Using recently acquired cable bacteria genomic information and synthetic biology approaches, the Fellow plans to reconstruct cable bacteria phenotypes in a lab-tractable organism, Shewanella oneidensis MR-1, to begin testing the genetic components underlying this unique multicellular microbial phenotype. The Fellow will use synthetic biology approaches to program filament formation and train in electrochemical, scanning-probe, and spectroscopic techniques to examine intercellular electron transfer in these synthetic cables. This transformative, systems-based research project will establish the first sequence-function relationships of cable bacteria genes and will be the first step toward decoding the Rules of Life governing long-distance electron transfer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microorganisms contribute to Earth-scale biogeochemical processes by regulating electron transfer across a range of spatial scales. The research goal of this project was to investigate the Rules of Life that govern long-distance electron transfer (LDET) through multicellular assemblies of bacteria. To address this question, we developed new strategies to synthetically program how bacterial cells assemble into multicellular communities and used electrochemical approaches to interrogate the conductive properties of these multicellular assemblies. Specifically, we developed a biofilm lithography approach in the electroactive bacterium Shewanella oneidensis. We used an optogenetic system to control the production of adhesive cell-surface proteins allowing the geometry of biofilms to be controlled by light. We used this system to pattern biofilms onto bespoke interdigitated electrodes to make biophysical measurements of the conductive properties of these cellular films over micrometer distances. This system enabled the first measurements of the conductivity through 2-dimensional S. oneidensis biofilms as well as the temperature-dependence of this phenomena. Extending on this, we enabled tunable control over biofilm conductivity by combining the optogenetic systems with a chemogenetic system to control the production of the extracellular metalloproteins that enable electron transport through the biofilms. Measurement and synthetic control over this material property shed fundamental insights into the Rules of Life governing long-distance electron transfer (LDET) which will enable future engineering of living electronic devices for applications in biosensing and biosynthesis. 

In addition to developing a synthetic system for investigating long-distance electron transfer (LDET), this project also supported benchmarking of this system to environmentally isolated multicellular bacteria. Cable bacteria were discovered to perform long-distance electron transfer (LDET) through filaments of hundreds of cells spanning centimeter-scale redox gradients found in sediment environments. Thus far, it has not been possible to isolate and grow cable bacteria in pure culture, requiring enrichment of cable bacteria filaments from environmental samples. I spent the final year of my NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology (PRFB) as a visiting research fellow in the Center for Electromicrobiology at Aarhus University in Denmark. To complement the synthetic biology and biophysics work, I trained in environmental microbiology isolating and enriching cable bacteria from sediments in Denmark and measuring their conductive properties. Additionally, we combined these two systems to investigate the ability for S. oneidensis to interact with cable bacteria in sediment imaging devices that enabled us to monitor the localization of fluorescently labelled S. oneidensis cells. In addition to training in laboratory and field research techniques, this experienced enabled opportunities to engage with the international community focusing on studying electromicrobiology. These experiences enabled the development of close research collaborations with the leading research groups working on cable bacteria in both Denmark and Belgium that will extend beyond this project. 

The educational goal of this project was to develop educational resources for training students in themes in electromicrobiology and synthetic biology. Working with a high-school student we co-developed an educational exercise for illustrating fundamental concepts in microbial fuel cells (MFCs). Specifically, we developed a Paper-based Organism Waste Energy Recovery (POWER) device that allows for students to prepare standalone devices from simple materials (i.e., paper, glue, and wires) and to measure voltages using a multimeter. These devices can be used as educational resources in resource-limited settings. While in Denmark, exercises from this development were utilized to illustrate MFCs to Danish high-school students visiting the Center for Electromicrobiology. Additionally, I co-developed open-source curricular resources for teaching synthetic biology while serving as the Education Liasson for the Student and Postdoctoral Association of the Engineering Biology Research Consortium.  

During my PRFB, I engaged in several professional development and community activities as a PRFB fellow. I mentored undergraduate and graduate students both at the University of Southern California and at Aarhus University. I communicated directly with US and Danish high-school students about core scientific concepts in electromicrobiology and synthetic biology as well as about careers in scientific research.  

In addition to these accomplishments, the PI published 7 peer-reviewed articles in multiple journals including ACS Synthetic Biology, Microbial Biotechnology, Protein Science, and Biochemistry, published an informative essay in The Microbiologist, and presented the findings of this project at 8 scientific conferences, 2 virtual seminars, and 6 university seminars. The PI also received and accepted an Assistant Professor position at Princeton University.
